I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 

 
1. 
equity investment of up to $25.2 million1 in the ADM Maculus Fund II L.P. (Maculus II). 
 

II. 

INTRODUCTION AND RATIONALE 

Macro- and Microeconomic Background and Rationale 

 
A. 
 
2. 
In  the  early  1990s,  Asia  experienced  explosive  capital  inflows.  Attracted  by  the  Asian 
miracle, Japanese and Korean banks (which accounted for over 55% of all credit provided to the 
Asian  private  sector),  along  with  European  and  US  investors,  bought  Asian  loans  and  bonds. 
Coincidently, the domestic private sector was taking full advantage of these countries’ pegged 
currencies and the advantages of foreign versus local borrowing costs available at the time. In 
July  1997,  following  a  period  of  slowing  exports,  rising  current  account  deficits,  and  depleted 
central  bank  reserves,  Asian  currencies  unpegged  from  the  US  dollar,  creating  a  systemic 
financial  collapse.  Par-based  lenders  faced  mounting  portfolio  losses,  weak  bankruptcy  codes 
and legal enforcement, poor legislative and judiciary protection, and no secondary market. The 
result was substantial amounts of nonperforming loans (NPLs), both official and unofficial, as a 
percentage of total loans.  
 
3. 
Market  estimates  are  that  one  to  two  thirds  of  all  loans  provided  in  Asia—outside 
Japan—are considered delinquent. This amounts to over $400 billion, at minimum of distressed 
assets in Asia (Figure 1).

 2 

  
 
 

  

Many of these distressed companies are struggling while talks with creditors continue to 
4. 
stall.  In  many  cases,  the  lack  of  progress  stems  from  a  complete  breakdown  of  trust  and 
understanding between different creditor groups, borrowers, management, and shareholders. In 
an  environment  where  the  legal  system  is  frequently  neither  robust  nor  creditor-friendly, 
negotiated  settlement  is  key.  However,  with  mistrust  prevailing,  negotiated  settlements  are 
unlikely  to  start  or  succeed.  Until  this  distressed  debt  problem  is  cleared,  the  companies 
concerned cannot grow or borrow. 
 
Restructuring  of  these  distressed  companies  could  be  much  improved  by  having  a 
5. 
source  of  capital  to  buy  out  existing  creditors  (take-out  capital).  Once  trust  is  broken,  in  most 
cases,  creditors  value  cash  much  more  highly  than  any  term-restructured  solution.  Once  a 
company  has  gone  into  financial  distress,  capital  to  finance  such  restructuring  is  extremely 
difficult  to  find  as  (i)  banks  tend  not  to  lend  to  companies  in  default,  (ii)  hedge  funds  are 
reluctant  to  step  into  complex  situations  where  they  are  unfamiliar  with  local  laws  and 
personalities, (iii) mezzanine debt2 and other capital providers demand too high a price on their 
investments, and (iv) original shareholders and their supporters are reluctant to show the value 
of their assets in case creditors seize them. 
 
6. 
Maculus  II  will  bridge  this  gap  and  take  out  certain  creditor  groups  to  initiate  sensible 
financial  and/or  corporate  restructuring  of  the  investee  portfolio  companies.  Maculus  II  will  not 
interfere in running the portfolio companies and will restrict itself to facilitating rehabilitation and 
financial restructuring. However, Maculus II will seek to offer more benefit to portfolio companies 
than  other  market  investors.  For  example,  it  may  aim  to  obtain  the  right  to  advise  portfolio 
companies on restructuring terms or name people associated with its general partner to portfolio 
company boards, or creditor and/or restructuring committees. If new management is required, a 
pool  of  resources  is  available  and  well  known  to  the  general  partner.  Maculus  II’s  overall 
investment  philosophy  will  be  to  maximize  investor  returns  over  the  medium  to  long  term  by 
adding value as an active investor in the portfolio companies. 
 
7. 
Disgruntled  and  frustrated  creditors  are  often  willing  to  give  up  some  attainable  gains. 
This is reflected in the sharp upward swing often seen in company share prices when they are 
rehabilitated.  
 
8. 
Maculus II will foster and build on the existing signs that debtors and creditors are willing 
to  work  toward  mutually  beneficial  solutions.  Some  driving  forces  behind  this  acceleration  are 
the recent rise in local stock markets, improved economic growth, under-leveraged banks, and 
low interest rates. 
 
B. 

Public Sector Country Strategies and Interventions of the Asian Development

9. 
ADB’s proposed investment in Maculus II will build on its strategy of helping developing 
member  countries  tackle  the  burden  of  distressed  assets  and  NPLs  and  build  a  sound  and 
efficient financial sector. For example, in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), ADB helped the 
Cinda Asset Management Corporation (Cinda) deal with NPLs. ADB technical assistance (TA)3 
was  given  immediately  after  Cinda  was  established  to  (i)  provide  the  asset  management 
company  (AMC)  with  the  technology  to  complete  its  mandate  to  undertake  financial  and

III. 

THE PROPOSED FUND 

Objectives 

Background 

 
A. 
 
10.  Maculus II is a successor fund of Maculus I, in which ADB invested $20 million of a total 
of $138 million in 2004.5 The establishment of Maculus II follows the rapid deployment of capital 
of Maculus I. Maculus II will build upon the success of the first fund and its strategy. 
 
B. 
 
The objectives of Maculus II are to (i) mobilize foreign capital flows to financially troubled 
11. 
but  potentially  viable  companies  throughout  Asia;  (ii)  catalyze  the  financial  restructuring  and 
rehabilitation of these companies to (a) optimize their asset and capital utilization; (b) revitalize 
corporate  growth  and  increase  competitiveness;  (c)  increase  profitability,  employment,  and 
employee  well-being;  and  (d)  introduce  industry,  management,  environmental,  and  corporate 
governance best practices more widely in the region; and (iii) achieve a demonstration effect, as 
Maculus  II’s  transactions  will  have  a  multiplier  effect  by  creating  replicable  (best  practice) 
restructuring models for Asia’s emerging markets. 
 
C. 

Concept and Strategic Rationale  

12.  Maculus II will invest primarily in the capital structure (securities, loans, equity, or other 
assets) of potentially viable, listed, or unlisted companies that are financially distressed because 
of excessive debt and/or inappropriate capital and financial structure. These companies are at 
risk  of  bankruptcy  (i.e.,  liquidation  with  full  labor  retrenchment)  unless  financially  restructured. 
Maculus II, through its investment in the portfolio companies, will assist such restructuring. 
 
13.  Maculus  II  will  use  the  best-known  global  practices  and  experienced  professionals  to 
create  opportunities  for  capital  appreciation  through  repositioning,  rehabilitation,  development, 
and intensive management of distressed or underperforming assets. It will seek attractive risk-
adjusted returns by exploiting interim inefficiencies in the market for NPLs and will capitalize on 
the expertise of its sponsors in managing distressed assets.

 4 

  
 
 
The two major sources of distressed assets are governments and banks. Governments 
14. 
throughout Asia have attempted to rationalize and strengthen their banking systems, leading to 
the creation of state-sponsored AMCs in some of Maculus II’s targeted countries. The primary 
task  of  AMCs  is  to  take  nonperforming  assets  from  undercapitalized  banks  and  sell  them  to 
investors  at  market  prices.  Other  banks  have  performed  their  own  ad  hoc  sales  of  distressed 
assets through public auctions and private negotiated sales with end buyers. 
 
15. 
Until  recently,  most  domestic  institutions  have  been  unable  or  unwilling  to  write  down 
NPLs to market prices because of their weak capital positions. Financial institutions and AMCs, 
however,  have  become  increasingly  aggressive  in  selling  distressed  assets.  Banking  reforms 
and tax changes are the primary motivation for sale of assets, not economic value. Increasing 
government  pressure  or  incentive  creation  (as  in  India,  Philippines,  and  PRC)  and  renewed 
interest in equity markets have given banks further incentives to absorb such losses, and hence 
sell NPLs. Foreign institutions—financial and trade—once again see new lending or trade as a 
growth  area.  Dealing  with  NPLs  or  bad  debt  is  seen  as  a  distraction  to  management  and 
potentially negative for new business. Private negotiation and careful structuring often provide a 
rich pool of assets for distressed asset buyers. 
 
D. 

Operational and Investment Plan  

ADM is involved in ongoing discussions with several attractive investment opportunities. 
16. 
Given ADM’s rapid deployment of funds, the investment manager can apply lessons learned in 
Maculus  I  to  strengthen  its  deal  sourcing  and  execution  abilities.  There  are  significant 
investment  opportunities  in  Indonesia,  Thailand,  and  the  Philippines,  where  ADM  has  built 
strong  relationships  and  refined  its  understanding  of  complex  local  laws  and  regulations.  In 
addition to these markets, ADM has indicated that it will also target investments in Viet Nam, Sri 
Lanka, and Pakistan. 
 
Although  competition  in  the  distressed  debt  arena  is  expected  to  increase  because  of 
17. 
demand for higher yields from an increasing number of investors, ADM has differentiated itself 
from  the  competition  since  it  specializes  in  Asian  distressed  debt  (excluding  Japan)  while  its 
competitors  have  more  of  a  global  focus.  It  is  expected  that  ADM  will  continue  to  enjoy  a 
competitive position in the Asian market by concentrating its decision makers in the region and 
building on a long track record of innovative solutions. 
 
E. 
 
18.  Maculus II is denominated in US dollars, established in the Cayman Islands, and is an 
exempted limited partnership.6 Its term is 5 years from the date of closing, but may be extended 
for up to two consecutive 1-year periods at the discretion of the general partner.  
 

Structure and Size  

                                                
 
6  The  selection  of  the  Cayman  Islands  as  the  legal  domicile  is  in  line  with  international  practice  for  private  equity 
funds  to  structure  such  a  vehicle  most  efficiently.  Various  ADB-sponsored  funds  have  been  established  in  this 
jurisdiction.  The  Cayman  Islands  were  chosen  because  Maculus  II  can  obtain  permanent  tax  exemption,  thus  it 
provides  a  tax-efficient  domicile.  The  Cayman  Islands’  legal  system  is  based  on  English  law,  therefore  the  legal 
concepts  are  familiar  to  many  investors  in  developed  countries.  The  Cayman  Islands  have  also  significantly 
improved their anti-money-laundering regulations in recent years and have been removed from the Financial Action 
Task  Force  on  Money  Laundering  list  of  non-cooperative  countries.  The  limited  partnership  agreement  includes 
anticorruption,  anti-money-laundering,  and  anti-terrorism  provisions  requiring  the  general  partner  and  ADM  (as 
investment manager) to institute and maintain internal control procedures to prevent Maculus II from being involved 
in any money-laundering scheme, fraud, or other corrupt activity.

Sponsor  

ADB’s commitment will be up to $25 million or 25% of paid-up capital (whichever is less). 
19. 
ADB will not be the largest investor in Maculus II. The limited partners’ participation in Maculus 
II is covered under the limited partnership agreement, which has been fully negotiated and is in 
line with market practice and ADB standards. 
 
F. 
 
20. 
ADM  is  the  sponsor  of  Maculus  II,  and  will  be  its  investment  manager  and  main 
shareholder  of  the  general  partner.  ADM  has  developed  a  strong  track  record  identifying  and 
successfully  realizing  value  from  distressed  debt  opportunities  in  Asia,  and  is  one  of  Asia’s 
leading  specialist  managers  of  Asian  distressed  assets.  ADM  was  founded  in  1996  to  provide 
structured  financing  advice  to  government  and  corporate  borrowers  throughout  Asia.  In  1998, 
ADM  Hong  Kong  Limited  (ADM's  Hong  Kong,  China-based  entity)  became  a  licensed 
investment manager registered by the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission. ADM is 
owned by its founders and directors.  
 
Since  its  inception,  ADM  has  turned  over  in  excess  of  $3  billion  in  face  value  of 
21. 
distressed  debt  and  has  been  directly  involved  in  restructuring  over  $2  billion  in  distressed 
assets.  ADM’s  key  personnel  have  extensive  experience  in  Asia,  Asian  distressed  debt 
management,  capital  mobilization,  and  asset  restructuring.  Since  its  formation,  ADM  has 
developed  a  close  network  of  well-connected  local  partners  and  joint  ventures  in  Indonesia, 
Republic of Korea, Philippines, and Thailand to source deal opportunities and obtain an in-depth 
understanding of local market conditions.  
 
ADM has developed a strong track record in Asia identifying and successfully realizing 
22. 
value  from  distressed  debt  opportunities.  ADM  has  received  several  awards  for  the  Galleus 
Fund,  including  the  top  Asian  fund  in  Asian  Investor  Magazine’s  hedge  funds  All  Strategies 
category  (2002  and  2003).  ADM  manages  over  $220  million  in  Asian  distressed  debt,  $450 
million in two passive collateralized bond obligation and equity warrant pools sponsored by the 
Korean Government, and $50 million in other funds. 
 
G. 

Eligible Instruments  

23.  Maculus  II  will  invest  in  single  credit  situations,  mostly  through  direct  purchase  of  debt 
(securities or loans) and, to a lesser extent, equity issued by troubled Asian companies and NPL 
portfolios.  
 
24. 
The  geographical  focus  of  Maculus  II’s  investments  will  be  selected  ADB  developing 
member countries where restructuring of the banking and corporate sector is at an early stage. 
To diversify, Maculus II will invest no more than 35% of aggregate capital commitments in any 
one  country  and  no  more  than  15%  of  aggregate  capital  commitments  in  any  one  portfolio 
company.

Justification of ADB Investment 

1. 

Development Impact: Overview of Benefits of Distressed Asset 
Restructuring  

 
35. 
Through Maculus II, ADB will provide financial support to selected distressed companies 
and  the  banking  sector  in  Asia.  Maculus  II’s  objective  in  restructuring  distressed  asset  would 
help  deliver  development  impact  on  four  fronts,  each  as  described  below:  (i)  entrusted 
relationship,  (ii)  employment  preservation,  (iii)  efficiency  promotion,  and  (iv)  expansion 
opportunity. In assisting corporate restructuring, Maculus II will address a key weakness in the 
banking sector that, if left unchecked, may limit continued economic growth. Equity investments 
in funds are an established intervention by the Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD).  
 
36. 
First,  given  the  contentious  nature  of  distressed  debt  resolution  and  the  ensuing 
corporate restructuring, attaining an entrusted relationship among parties is crucial to implement 
the  process.  With  ADB  as  an  “honest  broker”  shareholder  in  Maculus  II,  ensuring  a  suitable 
code  of  conduct  with  regard  to  Maculus  II’s  interaction  with  distressed  clients,  the  target 
distressed  firm  and  original  creditors  will  gain  comfort  in  engaging  dialogue  with  Maculus  II  to 
consider  and  execute  the  resolution  plan.  Second,  by  providing  needed  capital  and  a 
restructuring  plan  to  the  distressed  client,  Maculus  II  will  directly  help  the  client  revitalize  its 
business,  which  will  result  in  long-term  employment  preservation,  and  even  expansion,  within 
the client firm. Third, such capital infusion from Maculus II will allow the client firm to refocus on 
its  operations  (rather  than  be  distracted  by  avoiding  and  negotiating  with  defaulted  creditors). 
This will result in improved operational efficiency for the previously distressed firm. Finally as a 
result of the restructuring capital and increased efficiency, the client firm could seize expansion 
business opportunities to grow its business. 
 
37. 
On a macro level, accelerating the Asian restructuring process is key to (i) regenerating 
regional  growth,  (ii)  preserving  investments  in  companies  or  projects,  and  (iii)  reestablishing 
confidence  so  that  new  investors  will  step  forward  to  finance  the  continuing  massive 
infrastructure  needs.  Restructuring  gives  the  finance  provider  some  ability  to  ensure  that 
controls, environmental standards, and corporate governance procedures are implemented and 
adhered to. The leverage in the debt restructuring process far exceeds the level of control of a 
private equity or other participant in corporate investment structures. For Asia as a whole, the 
presence of large numbers of defaulted companies weighs heavily on the banking and financial 
system.  Even  where  bad  debts  have  been  sold  or  transferred  to  AMCs,  the  large  numbers  of 
distressed companies dampen the economy as they are relatively unproductive. In some cases, 
closure may be the optimum solution, but in most cases the underlying companies continue to 

 

 
J. 
 

  

  

 

9

 
 
 

be  productive  and  recover  strongly  once  the  weight  of  bad  debt  is  removed.  This  is  a  direct 
result  of  the  cause  of  bad  debt  which,  in  many  cases,  was  effectively  currency  speculation, 
although many companies were unaware of this at the time. 
 
The Asian development experience has shown that economic growth is one of the most 
38. 
powerful weapons in the fight against poverty. Growth creates the need for labor, the main asset 
of  the  poor.  As  growth  continues,  private  sector  employment  becomes  the  major  source  of 
economic support for most workers and their families. Economic growth also increases the tax 
base, enabling governments to finance social services such as health and education.7  
 
39. 
Indirectly, Maculus II addresses the inherent weaknesses of the banking industry in Asia. 
Corporate  structuring  is  crucial  to  restore  the  health  of  the  banking  industry  in  the  targeted 
countries,  as  in  the  case  of  the  Republic  of  Korea  after  the  1997  financial  crisis.  The 
vulnerability  of  the  banking  system and  the  economy  is  a  result  of  rapid  growth  that  outpaced 
the  establishment  of  sound  regulation,  building  of  institutional  capacities,  and  formulation  of 
sound  corporate  governance  principles.  The  development  of  a  sound  and  efficient  financial 
sector  is  a  prerequisite  for  broad-based  private  sector-led  economic  development  that  will 
reduce poverty. Failure to solve the NPL problem will result in a further drain of resources and 
potential earnings, and will significantly impair capital. As credit costs increase to cover the cost 
of  NPL  losses,  financial  institutions  are  reluctant  to  make  fresh  loans.  Tighter  credit  restricts 
economic  growth,  as  enterprises  are  unable  to  access  capital.  The  sale  of  NPLs  will  alleviate 
these problems and help stimulate economic growth. 
 
40. 
The  benefits  of  resolving  an  NPL  crisis  are  well  proven,  judging  from  the  success  of 
countries outside Asia. For example, in the US or Sweden, when NPLs decreased, the national 
economies began  to  recover  and  grow;  companies  and  businesses  started  creating  new  jobs; 
and  investors—more  confident  of  a  country’s  long-term  growth  prospects—began  to  pump 
investment  capital  into  the  country’s  stock,  bond,  and  property  markets  as  well  as  individual 
companies and businesses. The development of banks’ credit profiles reflects this improvement. 
For  example,  Standard  and  Poor’s  recently  raised  in  2005  the  outlooks  of  Bank  of  China  and 
China Construction Bank from stable to positive. The outlook upgrades were a direct outcome of 
the improvement of the Government of the PRC’s support and the resulting improvement in the 
banks’  asset  quality  by  reducing  NPLs.  Standard  and  Poor’s  noted  that  these  banks  “have 
solidly  embarked  on  the  path  of  financial  reform.  This  trend  was  accompanied  with  a  boost  in 
provisioning and increase in balance sheet transparency.”8  
 

2. 

Development Impact: Maculus I and Maculus II 

 
41. 
The  financial  community  has  taken  notice  of  the  success  of  Maculus  I  in  combining 
developmental and environmental goals with financial restructuring to create profitable returns. 
Participants  in  the  restructuring  sector—investors,  banks,  companies,  and  their  advisers—are 
now much more receptive to methodologies sponsored by ADB. However, more work needs to 
be done to sustain this momentum. It is reckoned that there are still $400 billion–$1,000 billion 
of NPLs and impaired loans in the Asian financial system. Maculus I’s $138 million has punched 
well  above  its  weight  but  it  will  need  further  work  to  make  a  lasting  impact.  The  backing  of 
Maculus II by ADB will demonstrate ADB’s and ADM’s confidence that the methodologies used

have value to the communities concerned and allow further work and investment to demonstrate

42. 
ADM’s role in the development process has been to invest in and rehabilitate distressed 
Asian  companies  through  financial  restructuring.  The  restructuring  of  distressed  assets,  which 
have  an  adverse  financial  or  capital  structure,  has  several  development  benefits,  including  (i) 
motivating  management  and  shareholders  to  operate  assets  transparently  and  efficiently  to 
benefit creditors, shareholders, and the community; (ii) ensuring that “good” assets, which would 
have been liquidated by the creditors, continue to operate and generate a return; (iii) ensuring 
that “bad” assets, which are non-operating and have no chance of generating a sufficient return, 
are  liquidated  so  that  capital  can  be  deployed  more  effectively;  and  (iv)  promoting  good 
corporate governance so that management and shareholders operate assets transparently, as 
well as an environmentally sound approach to operations 
 
43. 
ADB’s involvement in Maculus I meant that the aims and objectives of Maculus II were, 
and  are,  radically  different  from  other  funds  in  this  sector.  While  other  funds  have  focused  on 
short-term  gains  from  downsizing  or  liquidation  of  assets,  ADM  has  focused  on  rehabilitation 
and  growth  within  the  context  of  satisfactory  environmental  standards. Motivating  the  investee 
companies to take the ADM route to better health, with additional costs such as environmental 
audits  and  working  within  a  more  transparent  and  ethical  framework  than  before,  was  only 
possible  because  of  (i)  the  written  policies  of  Maculus  II,  which  meant  there  could  be  no 
negotiation  on  these  issues;  and  (ii)  the  borrowers’  perception  that  Maculus  I  would  behave 
responsibly and ethically as it monitored the investment. 
 
The development impact is mainly indicated by how successful the restructuring of the 
44. 
distressed company was. In other words, an unsuccessful restructuring will lead to insolvency, 
and a successful restructuring will restore the status quo or even lead to new growth with further 
spill-over  effect  to  the  economy  as  a  whole.  This  is  the  main,  direct  developmental  impact 
achieved  by  this  type  of  intervention.  In  other  words,  the  level  of  success  of  the  restructuring 
and

development  impact  and  the  internal  rate  of  return  (IRR)  of  Maculus  II’s  investments  are 
positively correlated, too; i.e., the IRR increases because the restructuring was successful and 
equity prices go up and debt gets repaid as the respective company again develops positively. 
The  high  level  of  confidence  of  existing  and  new  investors  in  the  returns  of  Maculus  II 
demonstrates their confidence in the developmental impact.9 
 
45.  Maculus  I  was  57.5%  invested  in  the  first  year  (over  90%  invested  in  the  first  17 
months),  ensuring  that  investors  were  not  paying  unnecessary  fees  on  committed,  but  un-
invested, funds. Maculus II has already produced healthy returns. Maculus I has demonstrated 
that good returns are not necessarily compromised by an “ethically focused” investment style. 
 
46. 
Lessons  Learned.  Maculus  I  demonstrated  that  several  factors  are  necessary  to 
prevent  distressed  situations  and  enable  sensible  restructuring,  including  (i)  a  stable  and 
reliable  legal  system  and  regulatory  framework  with  particular  regard  to  security  (e.g.,  title 
registration) and bankruptcy/foreclosure laws; (ii) management of companies within parameters 
and  restricted  business  environment  stipulated  by  lenders;  (iii)  strong  corporate  governance, 
which guarantees checks and balances to avoid management decisions that put companies at 
risk  (e.g., unsustainable  expansion  plans,  backed  by  borrowings  not  correlated  to  actual  cash

3. 

Role of ADB and Value Added 

 
47. 
Specifically, ADB’s continued involvement as an investor will help maintain these value-
added inputs: (i) continued support for Maculus II’s environmental analysis in deal due diligence 
and ongoing portfolio company monitoring; and (ii) additional support for recently revised ADB 
policies regarding anticorruption, anti-money-laundering, and anti-terrorism representations and 
covenants. In addition, it will (i) stimulate and facilitate reforms in the targeted countries, push 
governments  to  revise  laws  and  regulations,  and  create  an  appropriate  legal  and  regulatory 
framework;  (ii)  support  government  initiatives  to  pursue  financial  sector  reforms  aimed  at 
resolving problems caused by mounting NPLs; and (iii) provide modern, replicable, and market-
tested  mechanisms  for  NPL  and  distressed  asset  resolution,  creating  benchmarks,  bankable 
structures, and enhancing trust in the legal and regulatory environment. 
 
48. 
Investing  in  Maculus  II  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  strategy  of  promoting  (i)  poverty 
reduction through job preservation and creation; (ii) private sector development; and (iii) country 
strategies  addressing  issues  such  as  introducing  best  practices  in  corporate  governance, 
banking reform, NPL resolution, and infrastructure preservation and development. 
 
49. 
Investment in Maculus II is a logical continuation of ADB’s work with ADM based on the 
successful results, in terms of projected financial returns and Maculus II’s impact on corporate 
governance and development impact in Asia.

52. 
The  envisaged  exit  mechanisms  for  Maculus  II’s  investments  will  vary  depending  on 
holding  periods,  market  conditions,  expected  future  growth,  tax,  and  other  considerations. 
Typically  for  debt,  the  exit  route  after  restructuring  in  the  current  climate  will  be  refinancing 
through local bank debt or a debenture issue. For equity holdings, exit routes may be to sell the 
investment  to  the  original  shareholders,  other  strategic  buyers,  competitors,  or  via  an  initial 
public offering (IPO). Other exit routes include selling the debt instruments or their derivatives to 
another investor, asset sales, and repayment from cash flows.
